channel.title: Milestone OC Application
channel.description:
This application is awesome! Basically, it was written for the milestone because the locked boot loader doesn't allow any non-stock kernels to be loaded, so it couldn't be over clocked the traditional way of loading alternate kernels. It works by loading a kernel module that allows you to change steps, voltage, and frequencies.
This particular application is for the original Droid 1. It works on other phones, but I'm not sure if this particular .apk does or not. Basically, download the file here: [url=http://db.tt/71f4R3T]MilestoneOverclock147_prime.apk[/url]
Open it, click to load the module, set the max frequency you want, and click apply.
The full tutorial where I discovered this is here: http://www.droidforums.net/forum/cyanogenmod/107143-tut-milestone-oc-application-tut.html
As to the results? My stock droid running the latest stable cyanogenmod 6.1.2 scored thusly using Quadrant:
stock: 836 1000mhz: 1403 1200mhz: 1666
Those upper two are both better than the score of the nexus one, droid x, and evo. It's actually the highest score Quadrant lists: [img]http://img340.imageshack.us/img340/7919/snapshotfp.png[/img]
Anyway, I'm really happy and impressed. I no longer have to wait for the home screens to load every time I press home, it's practically instant. I'll report on battery life later... :/

item.title: Milestone OC Application
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Greeny:

I really want a new android phone now so I can get it OCed to like 2ghz+. All of a sudden 700Mhz is bugger all! It’s like 1998 all over again except now the device is handheld!

550Mhz for me :’(
I want to hold out for a Tegra 2 device, but I’m Canadian so it’s a long ways off for me.

Read full topic

That app costs, and I bet it uses the same module as this one. What a rip-off

Droid Life – 22 Oct 10

JRummy Releases Droid X/2 Overclock App, 1.45GHz Speeds and...

JRummy, one of our favorite ROM developers of all time released his Droid X and 2 overclock app this morning and it doesn't disappoint. We told you about the Unstable Apps release earlier, but this is another option that I highly recommend. The UI is...

Open it, click to load the module, set the max frequency you want, and click apply.
